snippet.title: One-minute auction battle scores seven figure sale - realestate.com.au
snippet.content:
sold in a minute at its July 29 auction.
A TOWNHOUSE has sold at an auction lasting less than sixty seconds. The speedy result followed a rapid-fire bidding battle that took it to a seven-figure sale price more than $200,000 above the reserve. Professionals Whiting and Co St Kilda director Dannie Corr said the property at was the subject of a short, sharp contest. "When bidding started, I'd say it took under a minute," Mr Corr said. The competition began with a $1.4 million bid, which was already above the reserve price for the property, he added. "The opening bid was what we call a Muhammad Ali bid - they were wanting to make a knockout bid which it certainly was, save for one other person," Mr Corr said. "So just the two of them competed like guns firing." The hammer fell at $1.5 million, with the opening bidder winning the keys. Mr Corr said the sale price was approximately $250,000 above the reserve. "It was a very good result," he said. Mr Corr said the two bidders were both local buyers, who had been motivated by seeing an earlier auction a few doors up the road achieve a hefty sale price.
Timber floors, a fireplace and a paved courtyard are features of the home.
The three-bedroom townhouse features a rooftop terrace, a double garage, and a neutral interior with timber floors, stone benchtops and a fireplace. It is walking distance from Albert Park Lake, the beach and the St Kilda light rail. "I think a lot of it was about the position," Mr Corr said. "Its also a very appealing home, it was bright and it had a very St Kilda feel." The property attracted strong inquiry throughout the campaign, he added. "It received a lot of interest, some interstate, too," Mr Corr said. St Kilda West offered a great deal of appeal to buyers considering its small size, with a mix of property styles and good amenities, according to Mr Corr. "It's only a very small pocket, and has a lot of period architecture and wide, tree-lined streets," he said. "It has the beach, parks, transport and access to restaurants and bars."
